title: No Reset Button: Reinventing Amplitude in a Post-AI World (Spenser Skates)

rawLines.text: Innovation is the biggest driver of
long-term growth. Amplitude's core
advantage is we built a machine that can
out innovate any of the competition out
there. Getting a lead in a very crowded
market. As a result, as a founder, CEO,
you are always leading from the front.
As large company executive though, it
flips. Your mentality shifts from how do
I lead from the front to that wasn't
really good enough. You guys got to do a
better job on this. That's really,
really hard. Look at the roles of what a
king is across different societies. You
have to be the chief general, the chief
justice, and you have to be the chief
priest. Fast forward to modern times and
what the role of CEO or executive is at
a company is actually quite similar. You
have to say, "Where are we going? What's
the strategy?" And then you need to
rally and inspire
[Music]
people. Welcome to Grit. I'm Jubin,
partner at Kleiner Perkins, a show where
we go beyond the highlight reel and
explore the personal and professional
challenges of building history-making
companies. Today we have Spencer Skates,
the CEO and co-founder of Amplitude, the
man who turned a data problem into a
billion-dollar business when he was 22
years old coming out of MIT. In 2021, he
took Amplitude public and now a ton of
people use it. But more interestingly,
Spencer has become very philosophical
and thoughtful about the way he thinks
about being a CEO and founder. Enjoy the
episode. You come from
the internet and cloud era of SAS
companies. We do. Yeah. You know. Yes.
And it's almost like that era is a bit
of the redheaded stepchild right now.
Yeah. You know, technology cycles always
come in waves, I
think. You had the, you know, so you
had Yeah. cloud applications and SAS,
you had big data, you had mobile, all of
which we're a part of. Um, and then more
recently you've had crypto. Um, and then
most recently, of course, you'd have AI.
And so, you know, this stuff comes in
waves and it um goes the interesting
part is that there's a
lot I think AI is still very early in
the data space. If you look at what a AI
is great at, it's like sifting through
and understanding large data sets and
surprisingly there's there's not been
actually much activity within our
domain. So if you look at data data
analytics
um understanding of user behavior there
there there'sn't really anything
actually there's nothing. So and so I
think there's a there's an exciting
opportunity for us done right um but
it's early days on it. So, do you think
that do you worry that the person that's
going to write the data story in your
category is going to be some upstart AI
company that that fundamentally builds
this from the ground up with a new tech
stack? Yeah, we're very architecture.
We're very paranoid about that. The the
the thing that's different about this
space though is that
the chat like chat GPT all the textbased
models you know midjourney all the image
based models they're all based on open
source data sets and so those are widely
available on the internet. when you
start thinking
about user data or customer data, um
there's only a few companies that have
large data sets on that and we're one of
them. Um so we
have trillions of data points across,
you know, billions of users doing all
sorts of things and lots and lots of
different web, mobile apps, other other
types of applications. And so there's
not like this open source data set that
you can just create a model and train
on. Um, and so we're one of the few
companies that's in a position to do
something like that. Um, which is a very
exciting place for us to be. Now, you
know, does that still mean that, you
know, some other company can't come
along and potentially do it? Like, no.
Like, yeah. So, we're we're paranoid
about that. So, we did this acquisition
at the end of last year, Command AI, um,
where their team is working on parts of
that. You know, we're going to be coming
out with an agent, uh, later this year
that does a whole bunch to help you
understand, explore, uh, act on the data
set that you have. uh in terms of your
users because products now I'm getting
the whole pitch for um amplitude
but software is this static thing like
Juben the the copy you get of an
application is the same as the one as I
get is the same as one as like every
person in the world gets but really
software should be customized on a per
person basis that gives us an ability to
create a product experience that's
customized for you or customized for me
or customized for every single person
out there so we're in the very early

special position because we have this
data set um that's not you know there's
no open source equivalent no w it's not
widely available. Yeah. Like the maybe a
reframing of that is that as the
incumbent you have a data advantage.
However, as the incumbent you have an
architectural disadvantage. Absolutely.
because of the 8 years of baggage that
you've been building. 13 years 13 years
of baggage in this case baggage that
you've been building on a tech stack
that might look very different in the
future. Yeah. Right. Yes. Yes.
Absolutely. Like that's that that's the
kind of the question in the industry
right now. Absolutely. Yeah. Yeah. And
like and don't get me wrong, I mean
running a $300 million public company,
it's like, you know, my brain is like
pulled in all sorts of directions. You
got to, you know, make sure we have good

I it's very hard for me to be singularly

totally like in some
ways do you ever feel the
urgency uh of like a refounding of this

you have a team that's insulated from

It's like you know we have this product

that's what I think a lot about which is
like how do you create the right

driving a whole bunch of innovation.
Yeah. And is it as something as simple

acquire them into amplitude and then
drive bring that mentality because

everyone they just want to be part of
corp dev and they they want to be part

be they have to be hyperfocused. They
they can't be thinking about, well,
what's our strategy to synergize with

no, no, no. They just have to be

yeah, it took us a while to to get that

I just got off part of the reason I was
late is I just got off a call with my

there is stuff and so one of the one of

So, that that's actually the thing I

creates friction. I mean, it's it's a

because we have the best analytics not

And I'll be the same on the AI thing.
like the reason we'll be great there is

working on a zero dollar business and so

think
um I think the the complaint I always

what they said recently was, "Oh, I

I don't I agree with all agree with

that maybe the public markets aren't the

Um and
so you know yeah like you let me so so
we're talking about taking a business

like founders just don't want to go out,
